title-group.article-title: Optimization of multiple tuned mass dampers for vibration control of system under external excitation

article-meta.aff: Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, India

author-notes.corresp: RS Jangid, Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay, Powai, Mumbai – 400 076, India Email: rsjangid@civil.iitb.ac.in

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Using a numerical searching technique the optimum parameters of multiple tuned mass dampers (MTMD) for suppressing the dynamic response of a damped main system subjected to external excitation are investigated. The criteria selected for the optimality is the minimization of the steady-state displacement of the main system under external harmonic excitation. The parameters of the MTMD that are optimized include: the damping ratio, the tuning frequency ratio and the frequency band-width. The optimum parameters of the MTMD system and corresponding steady-state displacement are obtained for different damping ratios of the main system and the mass ratios of the MTMD system. The explicit formulae for the optimum parameters of MTMD (i.e. damping ratio, band-width and tuning frequency) are then derived using a curve-fitting scheme that can readily be used for engineering applications. The error in the proposed explicit expressions is investigated and found to be quite negligible. The effectiveness of optimally designed MTMD system is also compared with that of the optimum single tuned mass damper and it is observed that the optimally designed MTMD system is found to be more effective for vibration control than the single tuned mass damper. Further, the damping in the main system significantly influences the optimum parameters and the effectiveness of the MTMD system. Finally, a sensitivity analysis of optimally designed MTMD system to study its performance under uncertainty in the parameter is also carried out.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The tuned mass damper (TMD) is a classical engineering device consisting of a mass, a spring and a viscous damper attached to a vibrating main system in order to attenuate any undesirable vibration. The natural frequency of the damper system is tuned to a frequency near to the natural frequency of the main system. Thus, the vibration of the main system causes the damper to vibrate in resonance, as a result, the vibration energy is dissipated through the damping in the TMD. The solution for determining the optimum tuning frequency and the optimum damping of a TMD for an undamped main system subjected to harmonic external force over a broad band of forcing frequencies is described by Brock (1946) and Den Hartog (1956). Using Den Hartog's procedure Warburton and Ayorinde (1980) have derived the optimum damper parameters for the undamped main system subjected to the harmonic support motion where the acceleration amplitude is fixed for all input frequencies. The explicit formulae for the optimum parameters of a TMD and its effectiveness are available under different combinations of system response and excitation (Warburton 1982; Tsai and Lin 1993; Fujino and Abe 1993, Bakre and Jangid 2004).

The main disadvantage of a single TMD is its sensitivity to the error in the natural frequency of the structure and/or that in the damping ratio of the TMD. The mistuning or off-optimum damping significantly reduces the effectiveness of a TMD. As a result, the use of more than one TMD with different dynamic characteristics has been proposed in order to improve the effectiveness. Iwanami and Seto (1984) had shown that two TMDs are more effective than a single TMD. However, the improvement on the effectiveness was not significant. The multiple tuned mass dampers (MTMD) with distributed natural frequencies were proposed by Xu and Igusa (1992) and also studied by Yamaguchi and Harnpornchai (1993), Abe and Fujino (1994), Jangid (1995, 1999), Bakre and Jangid (2007), Li (2000, 2002, 2006), Casciati and Giuliano (2009) and Marano and Greco (2011). It is shown that the MTMD is more effective for vibration control as compared to the single TMD. In addition, the effectiveness of the MTMD system is not much influenced by the change or estimation error in the natural frequency of the structure. Although, there have been several studies on the effectiveness of the MTMD system concluding that the MTMD is more effective than single TMD, very few studies are reported which investigate the optimum parameters of the MTMD for practical engineering applications under various excitation and system response. In the present study, the optimum parameters of the MTMD system for damped main system are investigated where the main system is excited under harmonic excitation.

The specific objectives of the study are: (i) to obtain the optimum parameters of the MTMD system which reduces dynamic response of the system, using the numerical searching technique, (ii) to compare the optimum parameters and the effectiveness of the MTMD system with corresponding single TMD system, (iii) to study the effects of damping of the main system on the variation of optimum parameters of the MTMD system and (iv) to derive the explicit mathematical expressions for the optimum parameters of the MTMD for practical application using curve fitting scheme and conduct the error analysis on the proposed expressions.

sec.title: 2. Structural model
sec.p:
The system configuration consists of a main system supported by n number of TMDs with different dynamic characteristics as shown in Figure 1. The main system is idealized as a single lumped mass characterized by the stiffness, ks , the damping constant, cs , and the mass, ms . It is assumed that the damping in the main system is of viscous type specified by the damping ratio, ξs (i.e., ξs=cs/2msks). Similar to the main system, the parameters of the jth TMD are the stiffness, kj , the damping constant, cj , and the mass, mj . The main system and each TMD are modeled as a single degree-of-freedom (d.f.) system under harmonic excitation so that the total d.f. of the combined structural system are n + 1. Figure 1.
Structural model of main system with multiple tuned mass dampers.

The natural frequency, ωj (i.e., ωj=kj/mj) of the jth TMD is expressed by (1)ωj=ωT [1+ (j-n+12 )βn-1 ] and (2)ωT=∑j=1 nωj/n
(3)β=ωn-ω1ωT where ωT is the average frequency of all MTMD; and β is the non-dimensional frequency band-width of the MTMD system. Note that equation (1) indicates that the distribution of the natural frequencies of the MTMD system over a specified band-width is linear.

As suggested by Xu and Igusa (1992) that the manufacturing of the MTMD with uniform stiffness is simpler than that with varying stiffness. As a result, the distribution of natural frequencies of the MTMD is obtained by keeping the stiffness constant but varying the mass of each TMD (i.e., k1 = k2 = …. kn = kT).
The damping constant of the jth TMD is expressed as (4)cj=2mjξTωj where ξT is the damping ratio kept constant for all the MTMD.
Total mass of the MTMD system is expressed by the mass ratio defined as (5)μ=∑j=1 nmjms where µ is the mass ratio of the MTMD system.
Tuning frequency ratio of the MTMD system is expressed by (6)f=ωTωs where ωs (i.e., ωs=ks/ms) is the natural frequency of the main system.
The main system is excited by the harmonic force expressed by (7)F(t)=F0eiωt where F(t) is the excitation force at the main mass; F0 is the amplitude; ω is the circular frequency; and i=-1.

The (n + 1) equations of motion for system shown in Figure 1 are expressed as (8) [M ] {X·· }+ [C ] {X· }+ [K ] {X }={F} where (9a) {X }= {xs,x1,x2,…,xn }T is (n + 1) vector for displacement response relative to the base and {F} is force vector (9b) {F }= {F(t),0,0,…,0 }T

The matrices, [M ], [C ] and [K ], are expressed as (10) [M ]=dia[ms,m1,m2,…,mn]
(11) [C ]= [cs+∑cj-c1-c2..-cnc10..0c2..0....symcn ]
(12) [K ]= [ks+∑kj-k1-k2..-knk10..0k2..0....symkn ]
The steady state harmonic response of the system is obtained by substituting X (t )=X (ω )e-iωt, solving for X (ω ) (13)X (ω )= (ω2M-iω [C ]+K) )-1F0
Since the matrices [M ], [C ] and [K ] have non-zero terms along diagonal, the first row and first column, the inverse in the above equation can be evaluated by Cramer’s rule.

sec.title: 3. Response to harmonic excitation
sec.p: The amplitude of the steady state harmonic displacement of the main system, xs (ω ), to the excitation, F(t)=F0eiωt, (Xu and Igusa 1992) is expressed by (14)xs (ω )= [ks-iωcs-ω2ms-iωz (ω ) ]-1F0 where (15)z (ω )=iω∑j=1 nmj (ωj 2-2iωωjξj )ωj 2-2iωωjξj-ω2
The amplitude of the displacement of the main system is expressed in the normalized form as (16)R= |xs(ω) |F0/ks

sec.title: 4. Optimum multiple tuned mass dampers parameters for undamped system
sec.p:
In Figure 2, variation of the R against harmonic excitation frequency is shown for single TMD and MTMD system for an undamped and main system. The response R is plotted for four different damping ratios of the dampers (i.e., ξT = 0.01, 0.02, 0.03 and 0.05) with other parameters as µ = 0.01, β = 0.2 and f = 1. The figure indicates that the curve of R passes through the two fixed points for the undamped main system with a single TMD (refer the points P and Q) for all damping ratios of the TMD. This phenomenon of response is used to find out the optimum parameters of the single TMD for undamped system as described by Den Hartog (1956). However, for the MTMD system such common points do not exist for which the R intersects for all damping ratios. As a result, the closed form expressions for optimum parameters of the MTMD system cannot be obtained using the same procedure for the single TMD with undamped system. However, the numerical searching technique can be applied for obtaining the optimum parameters of the MTMD system. Similar techniques had been used by Tsai and Lin (1993, 1994) for the optimum parameters of a single TMD with a damped main system and by Jangid (1999) for an undamped main system with MTMD. Figure 2.
Variation of response amplitude R against harmonic excitation frequency for different damping ratio of the tuned mass dampers (μ = 0.01, β = 0.2 and f = 1).

For a given mass ratio, µ and number of MTMD, n, the parameters of the MTMD (i.e., ξT, β and f) are varied such that the displacement amplitude R of the main system attains the minimum value for all harmonic excitation frequencies. The constraints applied on the values of parameters for the optimization study are: 0 ≤ ξT < 1; 0 ≤ β < 2 and f > 0. These conditions satisfy (i) the natural frequencies of the MTMD are positive real and (ii) the MTMD are under-damped. The superscript opt is used to denote the optimum parameters and corresponding displacement amplitude R.

The values of the coefficients in equations (17) to (20) are given in Table 3. These values are obtained such that the mean square error is the minimum. Note that the first term in the above expressions denotes to the corresponding optimum value for the single TMD taken from reference Warburton (1982). A comparison of the optimum parameters obtained by numerical search technique and above expressions is shown in Figures 3 and 4. It is observed from these figures that there is a good agreement between the optimum parameters of the MTMD system by two approaches. The maximum error for any value of ξTopt, βopt, fopt and Ropt is observed to be 6.19, 4.27, 0.27 and 1.9%, respectively. The magnitude of error for optimum damping ratio is relatively more. This is due to the fact that the optimum damping ratio of the MTMD system is sufficiently low. From these figures, it is also observed that with the increase of number of MTMD the optimum damping ratio and displacement of the main system decreases whereas the optimum band-width and tuning frequency increases. On the other hand, the optimum damping ratio and band-width increases and tuning frequency and corresponding displacement of the main system decrease with the increase of the mass ratio of the MTMD system. Figure 3.
Comparison of optimum parameters by numerical searching technique and explicit expressions against the number of the multiple tuned mass dampers.
Figure 4.
Comparison of optimum parameters by numerical searching technique and explicit expressions for different mass ratios of the multiple tuned mass dampers.
Table 3.
Values of various coefficients in the explicit expression for optimum parameters for undamped main system
Coefficients Corresponding value
ξT opt βopt fopt Ropt
a1 0.539 0.4061 0.0109 0.3379
a2 0.0852 0.0404 0.7483 −0.1111
a3 −0.4706 −0.3591 −0.4129 0.1179
a4 0.775 −0.6992 −0.6906 −0.1237
a5 0.3582 −0.0907 0.0149 0.6391
a6 0.0299 4.8938 1.022 0.4233

sec.title: 5. Optimum multiple tuned mass dampers parameters for damped system
sec.p: In this section, the optimum parameters of the MTMD system with constant stiffness of each TMD using the numerical searching technique are obtained for minimization of the steady state displacement response of the main system. The optimum parameters of the MTMD system are obtained for four values of the damping ratios of main system (i.e., ξs = 0, 0.02, 0.05 and 0.1).

Figure 5 shows the variation of optimum parameters, ξTopt, βopt, fopt and Ropt against the number of TMDs for the mass ratio µ = 0.01. The optimum damping ratio, ξTopt, reduces sharply as the number of MTMD increases. The optimum damping ratio of single TMD is much higher than that for the MTMD system. Further, the optimum damping of the MTMD system increases with the increase of the damping of the main system. The optimum frequency band-width, βopt, of the MTMD system increases with the increase in both the number of MTMD as well as the damping of the main structure as shown in Figure 5. The optimum tuning frequency ratio, fopt, increases with the increase in the number of MTMD.However, it remains almost constant beyond a certain number of the MTMD (in this case for n > 5). The optimum tuning frequency for single TMD is smaller than that for the MTMD system. Also, the optimum tuning frequency ratio decreases with the increase in the damping of the main structure. The normalized displacement of the main system at optimum parameters, Ropt, initially decreases sharply and then remains constant with the increase in the number of MTMD. The Ropt of the MTMD system is less than that for a single TMD system confirming that an optimally designed MTMD system is more effective than the optimum single TMD system. As expected, the Ropt decreases with the increase in the damping of the main system. Figure 5.
Variation of the optimum parameters against the number of tuned mass dampers for μ = 0.01.

In Figure 6, the variation of ξTopt is plotted against the mass ratio, µ for different damping ratios of the main system with number of MTMD, n = 1, 5, 11 and 21. The optimum damping ratio increases with the increase in the mass ratio, being more pronounced for the single TMD as compared to the MTMD system. The optimum damping ratio for a single TMD is sufficiently larger than that for the MTMD system. Further, it is also observed that the ξTopt increases with the increase of the damping of the main system. Thus, the optimum damping ratio of the MTMD increases with the increase of the mass ratio and damping ratio of the main system. Figure 6.
Variation of the optimum multiple tuned mass dampers damping, ξTopt against the mass ratio, for f = fopt and β=βopt .

Figure 7 shows the variation of the optimum band-width, βopt of the MTMD system against the mass ratio of the MTMD. As the mass ratio increases, the optimum frequency band-width also increases. The optimum band-width is relatively higher for the higher number of the MTMD system. Further, it can also be seen from Figure 7 that as the main structure damping increases, the optimum frequency band-width also increases for a given mass ratio and the number of MTMD. Thus, the optimum frequency band-width of the MTMD system increases with the increase of both the mass ratio of the MTMD and the damping of the main system. Figure 7.
Variation of the optimum frequency band-width of the multiple tuned mass dampers, βopt against the mass ratio, for ξT = ξTopt and f = fopt.

In Figure 8, variation of the optimum tuning frequency ratio, fopt is plotted against the mass ratio of the MTMD. It is observed from the figure that the optimum tuning frequency decreases with the increase of the mass ratio. For a given mass ratio, the optimum tuning frequency ratio increases with the increase in the number of MTMD and decreases with the increase in the main system damping. However, the difference in the optimum tuning frequency ratio for n = 11 and 21 is not quite significant. Further, for the low values of the mass ratio, the optimum tuning is the same for single TMD as well as MTMD system. Moreover, the optimum tuning for a single TMD is much lower than that for the MTMD system for the higher values of the mass ratio. Thus, the optimum tuning frequency decreases with the increase of the mass ratio being more pronounced for the single TMD as compared to the MTMD system. Figure 8.
Variation of the optimum tuning frequency ratio, fopt against the mass ratio, ξT = ξTopt and β=βopt.

Figure 9 shows the variation of displacement of the main system at optimum parameters, Ropt against the mass ratio, µ. The Ropt decreases with the increase in the mass ratio and decreases with the increase in the number of the MTMD. However, the values of Ropt for n = 11 and 21 are not distinguishable and coincide with each other. The comparison of Ropt with the corresponding values without MTMD indicates that the reduction in the displacement response of the main system due to MTMD is the maximum for undamped system in comparison to the damped system. The effectiveness of the MTMD is found to be less for the main system having higher damping. Thus, the effectiveness of the MTMD and single TMD is reduced for the higher damping in the main system. Figure 9.
Variation of R opt against the mass ratio, μ, for ξT = ξTopt, β=βoptand f = fopt.

sec.title: 5.1. Explicit formulae for optimum parameters
sec.p:
Since the structural system considered is relatively complicated, therefore, it is extremely difficult to get the exact closed form expressions for the optimum parameters of MTMD system theoretically. However, the explicit formulae for optimum parameters can be obtained by applying the curve fitting technique, using the optimum parameters of the MTMD obtained by the numerical searching technique. The optimum parameters of the MTMD system will be function of the damping of main system, ξs, mass ratio, µ, and number of the MTMD, n. This implies that suitable curves shall be selected which is function of the three parameters (i.e., ξs, µ and n). It was observed that to select a curve of optimum parameters using these three parameters is very complicated. As a result, the closed form expressions for 11 number of MTMD are first obtained and these expressions are extended for the other number of the MTMD. After several trials and errors the following expressions of the optimum parameters are found for n = 11 that provide the minimum error. (21)ξTopt=3μ8(1+μ)-0.797698μ(0.539+0.0852μ-0.4706μ) +(a1+a2μ+a3μ)μξs+(a4+a5μ+a6μ)μξs2
(22)βopt=3.292046μ(0.4061+0.0404μ-0.3591μ) +(a1+a2μ+a3μ)μξs+(a4+a5μ+a6μ)μξs2
(23)fopt=11+μ+0.904222μ(0.0190+0.7483μ-0.4129μ) +(a1+a2μ+a3μ)μξs+(a4+a5μ+a6μ)μξs2
(24)Ropt=2μ (1+μ2 )-0.9062941μ (0.3379-0.1111μ+0.1179μ ) + {a1 (11-ξT )+a2 (11-ξT2 )+a3 (11-ξT4 ) } ×ξs1μ + {a4 (11-ξT )+a5 (μ-0.00251-ξT2 )+a6 (11-ξT4 ) } ×ξs1μ

The values of the coefficients (i.e., a1 to a6) in equations (21) to (24) are given in Table 4. These values are obtained such that the mean square error is the minimum. Note that the first term in the above expressions (i.e., equations (21) to (24)) denotes to the corresponding optimum value for the MTMD for undamped system with number of MTMD = 11 taken from the Section 4 (i.e., equations (17) to (20)). A comparison of the optimum parameters obtained by numerical search technique and from the proposed expressions is shown in Figure 10. It is observed from the figure that there is a good agreement between the optimum parameters of the MTMD system by two approaches. The maximum error for any values of mass and damping ratio is 6.22, 5.25, 0.71 and 7.95% for ξTopt, βopt, fopt and Ropt, respectively. The maximum error is less than 8% occurring for extreme mass ratio values which can be acceptable for all practical purposes. Figure 10.
Comparison of optimum parameters by numerical searching technique and explicit expressions for different mass ratios of the multiple tuned mass dampers for n = 11.
Table 4.
Values of various coefficients in the explicit formulae of optimum parameters for n = 11, for damped main system with constant stiffness of dampers
Coefficients Corresponding values
ξT opt βopt fopt Ropt
a1 0.344 6.3412 −2.1478 −10.5821
a2 −0.7946 −26.9012 1.8701 −0.3711
a3 1.1058 32.6981 2.775 9.7479
a4 0.7322 −11.2824 −2.1478 1.1263
a5 0.435 17.3472 0.8522 2.0791
a6 0.1107 33.7972 1.8583 −1.2567

The optimum parameters for number of MTMD, n = 5 and 21 are obtained by using a multiplication factor, Nd, to the corresponding optimum parameters for n = 11 (refer to equations (20) to (24)) and are expressed by (25)ξTopt=Nξ (ξTopt )11
(26)βopt=Nd β (βopt )11
(27)fopt=Nd f (fopt )11
(28)Ropt=Nd R (Ropt )11 where Nd ξ, Nd β, Nd f and Nd R are the multiplication factors for the ξTopt, βopt, fopt and Ropt, respectively for n = 5 and n = 21; and subscript 11 indicates the corresponding value of the optimum parameters for n = 11.

The values of the Nd ξ, Nd β, Nd f and Nd R for n = 5 and 21 are given in the Table 5 which are obtained such that the mean square error is the minimum. A comparison of the optimum parameters obtained by numerical search technique and above expressions is shown in Figures 11 and 12 for n = 5 and 21, respectively. It is observed from these figures that there is a good agreement between the optimum parameters of the MTMD system by numerical searching technique and proposed explicit formulae. The maximum error is found to be less than 5%. Figure 11.
Comparison of optimum parameters by numerical searching technique and explicit expressions for different mass ratios of the multiple tuned mass dampers for n = 5.
Figure 12.
Comparison of optimum parameters by numerical searching technique and explicit expressions for different mass ratios of the multiple tuned mass dampers for n = 21.
Table 5.
Values of various coefficients in the explicit formulae of optimum parameters for n = 5 and 21, for damped main system with constant stiffness of dampers
Coefficients Corresponding values
n = 5 n = 21
Nd ξ 1.41157 0.88561
Nd β 0.81678 1.07142
Nd f 0.99642 1.00472
Nd R 1.02240 0.99978

The explicit formulae obtained here are based on the mass ratio not greater than 0.1, a damping ratio in the range of 0 to 0.1 and the number of MTMD in the range of 5 to 21. This covers the fair range of practical applications of the MTMD system. The use of proposed expressions beyond the above range may produce relatively more error. However, the same technique can be applied to find out the corresponding expressions for the other ranges of mass ratios and number of MTMD.

sec.title: 6. Optimum multiple tuned mass dampers systems with constant mass of dampers
sec.p: This section deals with the comparison of the optimum parameters of the MTMD system with a constant mass of dampers whereas in the earlier Sections the optimum parameters were derived based on the constant stiffness of the MTMD. The optimum parameters are obtained using the numerical searching technique for minimization of the steady state displacement response of the main system. The optimum parameters of the MTMD system are obtained for the damping ratio of main system, ξs = 0.02 and number of dampers, n = 11 and 21. These optimum parameters are then compared with the corresponding optimum parameters for constant stiffness of dampers.

Figure 13 shows the comparison of optimum parameters namely band-width, tuning frequency, optimum damping ratio for dampers with constant mass and constant stiffness for n = 11. The optimum value of band-width and tuning frequency is more for constant stiffness of dampers as against for constant mass of dampers and the difference between the two increases with the increase of the mass ratio. On the other hand, the optimum value of damper damping is relatively higher for the system with a constant mass in comparison with the system with a constant stiffness. The value of Roptis more for the constant mass system in comparison with the constant stiffness system implying that the constant stiffness system is better for the vibration control of the structure with the corresponding constant mass system. Similar effects of comparison between constant mass and constant stiffness are observed for n = 21 as depicted in Figure 14. Figure 13.
Comparison of optimum parameters ξTopt, βopt, fopt and Ropt for constant mass of dampers and constant stiffness of dampers for number of dampers n = 11 (ξs = 0.02).
Figure 14.
Comparison of optimum parameters ξTopt, βopt, fopt and Ropt for number of dampers, n = 21 for constant mass of dampers and for constant stiffness of dampers (ξs = 0.02).

sec.title: 7. Sensitivity of optimum multiple tuned mass dampers systems
sec.p: It will be interesting to study the performance of an optimally designed MTMD system with uncertain structural parameters to know the change in the controlled response of the main system. As a result, in this Section, the response R of the main system with optimal MTMD is studied with error in the natural frequency of the structure and/or MTMD system. This will result in the mistuning of the dampers and expressed as a percentage tuning error (i.e. the difference in the actual and optimal tuning frequency ratio divided by the optimal frequency ratio).

Figures 15 and 16 show the variation of response amplitude R of the single d.f. system with optimal MTMD system against error in the tuning frequency ratio for an undamped and damped system, respectively. As expected, the steady state response of the system increases if the tuning frequency ratio is either increased or decreased in comparison with the optimal value. The change in the response was found to be more sensitive for the system with low structural damping and lower mass ratio. Thus, the effectiveness of the MTMD system is reduced due to uncertainty in the structural or damper frequency and these effects are more pronounced for a system with lower mass and damping ratios. Figure 15.
Variation of response amplitude R of the optimal multiple tuned mass dampers system against error in the tuning frequency ratio for undamped system.
Figure 16.
Variation of response amplitude R of the optimal multiple tuned mass dampers system against error in the tuning frequency ratio for undamped system (ξs = 0.05).

sec.title: 8. Conclusions
sec.p:
The optimum parameters of the MTMD system for a minimum steady state displacement of the damped main system to external harmonic excitation are investigated. The optimum parameters of the MTMD system (i.e., the damping ratio, tuning frequency and frequency band-width) are obtained using numerical searching technique for different values of number and mass ratio of the MTMD. A curve fitting technique is then applied to find out the explicit formulae for the optimum parameters of the MTMD system. The proposed explicit formulae had shown a good agreement with the corresponding optimum parameters obtained by numerical searching technique. From the trends of the results of the present study, the following conclusions may be drawn:
For the same mass ratio and damping in the main system, the optimally designed MTMD system is found to be more effective than the optimum single TMD system.
The optimum damping ratio of the MTMD system is found to be sufficiently low as compared to a single TMD. The optimum damping ratio increases with the increase of the mass ratio and damping of the main system, being more pronounced for a single TMD system as compared to an MTMD system.
Optimum frequency band-width of the MTMD system increases with the increase of both the mass ratio of the MTMD and the damping of main system.
Optimum tuning frequency of the MTMD system is found to be higher than that for a single TMD. Further, it is seen that the optimum tuning frequency decreases with the increase of the mass ratio and the damping of main system.
For the MTMD system, the optimum damping ratio decreases whereas the frequency band-width increases mildly with the increase of the number of MTMD.
The difference in the optimum parameters of the MTMD system between constant mass and the corresponding constant stiffness of the damper was observed and it increases with an increase of mass ratio.
The effectiveness of the MTMD system is reduced due to uncertainty in the structural or damper frequency and these effects are more pronounced for the system with smaller mass and damping ratios.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
